Mellora'b, R.G. Copperthwaitea'c, N.J. Covillea'* aCentre for Applied Chemistry and Chemical Technology, Department of Chemistry, University of the Witwatersrand, Private Bag 3, PO Wits 2050, Johannesburg, South Africa bAnglo American Research Laboratories (Pry) Limited, PO Box 106, Crown Mines 2025, South Africa CResearch and Development Department, AECI, Private Bag X2, Modderfontein 1645, South Africa Received 17 January 1997; accepted 16 April 1997 Abstract Novel Co-MnO and CoCr204 catalysts were found to be tolerant to sulfur up to levels of 220 ppm under WGS reaction conditions. However in coal-derived process gas containing between 0.25 and 0.3 mol% sulfur, and at a reaction temperature of 400 the Co-MnO catalyst deactivated rapidly and irreversibly with formation of bulk Co9S8 and a surface manganese sulfide species. The CoCr204 catalyst partially deactivated under similar conditions, a phenomenon related to the formation of a surface sulfate species. Bulk sulfiding of the CoCr204 catalyst to CoCr2S4 occurred at 550 and this catalyst gave near- equilibrium CO conversions in the WGS reaction. A pre-sulfided cobalt chromium catalyst demonstrated typical sulfur dependent mechanistic characteristics, with a maximum activity above 400. 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. Keywords: Water-gas shift reaction; Cobalt catalyst; Sulfur poisoning; Spinel 1. Introduction Catalyst poisoning has been identified as one of the most significant problems associated with the com- mercial application of catalysts [1] and has been the subject of extensive studies particularly with regard to accurately predicting catalyst lifetime and behavior. For example, the life of supported metal catalysts may be significantly reduced in the presence of parts per million quantities of sulfur contaminants in a feed stream [2-4]. In industrial plants which utilize coal- derived synthesis gas to produce chemicals or fuels, *Corresponding author. Fax: +27 11 3397967; e-mail: ncoville @ aurum.chem.wits.ac.za rectisol sulfur removal units and/or guard reactors [5] have thus proven necessary to protect various catalysts from H2S and COS present in the feed gases [6,7]. The WGS (water-gas shift) reaction catalysts have been found to be especially prone to sulfur poisoning. The commercial high temperature iron chromium catalyst deactivates in H2S or COS at concentrations above 50 ppm [8]. A further disadvantage is that the iron-chromium catalyst cannot be operated below 330-350 [9], which limits the theoretically obtain- able CO conversion. Alternative metal oxides [10,11] including the cobalt-molybdenum oxide (CoMoX) catalyst, which has been recognised as a stable, active WGS catalyst in the sulfided state [12-14] have thus been studied. Laniecki et al. [15] also showed that 0926-860X/97/$17.00 @ 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(97)001 5 8-0 70 J.R. Mellor et aL /Applied Catalysis A: General 164 (1997) 69-79 sulfided Ni-Mo-Y zeolite catalysts could catalyze the WGS reaction in a feed gas containing sulfur. A major drawback affecting the commercial applicability of CoMoX and other reported [16] catalysts for the WGS reaction have been that most coal-derived synthesis gas feedstocks contain insufficient sulfur to maintain a viable commercial activity. Recently, however, a Ti promoted Co-Mo-based catalyst has been reported [17,18] which extends the range of H2S concentration in which the catalyst can be operated. At present the identification of a high activity sulfur tolerant, rather than sulfur dependent, WGS catalyst has received little attention [10,19]. It is therefore evident that scope still exists to identify a WGS catalyst with significantly higher activity than iron chromium oxide which can be operated at a lower temperature and that can also be successfully employed in the presence or absence of feedstock sulfur [10]. Preliminary research carried out in our laboratories [10,20] showed that two cobalt-based high tempera- ture WGS catalysts namely, cobalt manganese oxide (Co :Mn=3 : 1) and cobalt chromium oxide (Co : Cr=3 : 1) showed promise in sulfur containing feed gas. The sulfur resistant characteristic dem- onstrated by the cobalt manganese oxide and cobalt chromium oxide catalysts were rationalized by the "protective mechanism" reported by Bartholomew [2]. It was hypothesized [19] that as the formation of manganese sulfides and chromium sulfides is ther- modynamically more favorable than the formation of cobalt sulfide, preferential sulfiding of the manganese and chromium catalyst supports took place leaving the cobalt component of both catalysts unchanged and unhindered (in this case) for actively catalyzing the WGSR. This paper expands on this research [ 10,19] both by characterizing the catalysts before and after sulfur treatment and by analyzing the performance of the catalysts in untreated, sulfur rich (0.25-0.3 mol%) process gas obtained from a coal-based ammonia synthesis plant. 2. Experimental Cobalt-manganese oxide (Co : Mn=3 : 1) and cobalt-chromium oxide (Co : Cr=3 : 1) catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation of mixed metal nitrate solutions with ammonia solution at a tempera- ture of 70, and a pH of 8.3.01 for cobalt- manganese oxide and 9.3.01 for cobalt--chrom- ium oxide. Atomic absorption (AA) data confirmed average atomic ratios of Co : Cr=2.88 : 1 and Co : Mn=3.!2 : 1. Catalyst particles (0.500- 1.180 mm) were calcined in air at 500 for 24 h and reduction was carried out in situ at 400 (H2 GHSV=200h-1) for 16 h unless otherwise stated. Catalyst characterization included the determination of bulk structure by XRD, using a Phillips PW1050 diffractometer, and BET surface area measurements. In situ XPS [20,21] was also used to determine the nature of sulfur adsorption onto the cobalt-based catalysts. Experiments were conducted in a Vacuum Generator "Solar 300" chamber (base pressure 4x 10-1bar) with a VG "CLAM 100" system com- prising of a standard (Mg/A1) water cooled anode and a LEG 61 electron gun, mounted in the chamber. These sources shared a 150spherical detector analy- zer and a channeltron detector. The catalyst reactor consisted of a Leybold-Heraeus VLP 10/63 prepara- tion chamber which was connected to a high pressure cell which was in turn linked to the UHV chamber. The catalyst disc was mounted on a molybdenum sample holder which fitted into a recess in a motor driven cylindrical rod. The sample was heated resis- tively by passing a current through the sample holder. A gas handling system allowed reactions to be carried out up to a pressure of 15 bar and at tempera- tures of up to 600. The reactor exit stream was fed through a GC for on-line analysis, the whole system being heated to prevent condensation of reaction products. A separate feed line for sulfur poisoning experiments was used, in order to minimize contam- ination of the system due to the sulfur. Hydrogen sulfide poisoning was performed as fol- lows. After catalyst reduction (400/l 6 h) in the XPS spectrometer the sample was flushed with N2 (400/ 16 h). A 1 ml pulse of 2% H2S/balance N2 (supplied by Afrox) was then syringed into the N2 carrier gas stream passed over the catalyst at atmospheric pres- sure. A similar procedure was adopted for the unre- duced catalysts i.e. for the addition of a H2S pulse at 400. Catalyst testing was conducted in a fixed-bed laboratory microreactor system with on-line sulfur analysis using a Hewlett Packard 5890A gas chroma- J.R. Simultaneous analyses of H2, N2, CO, CH4 and CO2 were achieved by means of a thermal conductivity detector after separation on a Carbosieve SII column at 100. Activity is reported on the basis of percent CO conversion for 24-0.1 ml of 0.500 to 1.180 mm catalyst particles. Coal-derived sulfur containing process gas for the WGS reactor of a coal-based ammonia plant was obtained from AECI, Modderfontein, South Africa. The average composition of the sulfur containing coal-derived process gas used was 24.9 mol% Hz, 3.8 mol% N2, 60.4 mol% CO, 10.9 mol% CO2, 0.249% COS and less than 0.003 mol% H2S. The activity of Co-MnO in coal-derived process gas A range of Co-MnO systems have been previously synthesized and studied by in situ XRD procedures [26]. The initial phase of the uncalcined oxide was found to be a mixed oxide spinel (Co,Mn)(Co,Mn)204 in which the Co and Mn cations occupied each site non-exclusively. Our XRD results for the 3 : 1 cobalt- manganese oxide were in agreement with this struc- ture. Reduction of the catalyst yielded a solid solution of the c~-cobalt in MnO [7]. The Co-MnO catalyst was calcined (500) and reduced in situ (400) and subsequently investigated for WGS activity. In the absence of sulfur, excellent activity and stability was obtained at 400 for 100 h (Fig. 4). At this stage the catalyst was subjected to the sulfur containing process gas and an immediate decrease in activity was noted. Although it appeared that an increase in activity occurred (15-20%) within 5-10 h of process gas use, the catalyst thereafter retained a low activity (6%) for the next 100 h on line. Similar profiles were obtained for repeat runs. Clearly, irreversible catalyst deactivation has occurred. An attempt was made to establish the reason for this deactivation using XRD and XPS techniques. At the end of the WGS reaction, performed in the presence of process gas (Fig. 4), the catalyst was analyzed and found to contain 9.25% sulfur (0.88% carbon). Both the surface area and the pore volume had decreased when compared to values measured for this reduced catalyst (33.1-7.5 m2g-1; 0.14-- 0.02cm3g-t). The XRD spectrum confirmed bulk sulfidation and revealed the presence of Co9S8, c~- cobalt, MnS and traces of MnO (in approximate order of abundance). XPS spectra were also obtained for the Co-MnO system (Fig. 5). Fig. 5a shows the photoelectron peaks for the calcined Co-MnO catalyst prior to reduction. The Co, 2p1/2 peak at 780.1 eV corresponds to Co2+/Co3+ oxidation states (see above) and the Mn peak at 641.9 eV to Mn3+, as expected. It can be seen (Fig. 6) that the CO conversion increased with temperature for all three reactions with a maximum activity of -4-93% achieved at temperatures above 350. At 500 CO conversion was independent of sulfur concentration. From Fig. 6 it can also be seen that the activity of the pre-sulfided cobalt-chromium catalyst increased with increasing sulfur feed concentration. The activity results obtained for the CoCr204 catalyst (Fig. 6) shows that the presence of sulfur in the feed promotes the WGS reaction, and suggests that the sulfur is actively participating in the shift reaction. It is well known that sulfur takes part in the hydrodesulfuriza- tion reaction sequence over Co-Mo-AI203 catalysts [28], whilst molybdenum sulfide is reported [29] to catalyze the WGS reaction by a redox cycle involving Mo(IV)/Mo(V) in the presence of sulfur-containing feed gas. Presumably a similar process is occurring for the CoCr204 catalyst in which the Cr takes the place of the Mo in the catalytic reaction. No evidence for the active participation of sulfur in the WGS mechanism of any sulfided or unsulfided cobalt-chromium catalyst combination has been pre- viously reported. 3.5. Activity of the pre-sulfided CoCl'2O4 and Co-Mo-AI203 catalysts as a function of GHSV and CO : H20 feed ratio An attempt was made to assess the catalytic activity of the pre-sulfided CoCr204 catalyst against a standard 78 J.R. Mellor et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 164 (1997) 69-79 industrial catalyst. This was achieved by determining the catalytic activity under comparable reaction con- ditions and by varying either the CO : H20 feed ratio or CO GHSV. The activity of the pre-sulfided CoCr204 and Co-Mo-A1203 catalysts in process gas (containing 0.7% sulfur) at CO : H20 feed ratios in the range 1.1-1.7 were studied. It was found that a change in the catalyst performance occurred within this range, namely, that the industrial catalysts had a consistently higher % CO conversion than the CoCr204 catalyst (97% versus 92%). Both the pre-sulfided CoCr204 and Co-Mo-A1203 catalysts showed a decrease in activity as the CO GHSV feed rate was varied between 200 and 1100 h ~ (CoCr204: conversion decreased from 94 to 84%; Co-Mo-A1203: conversion decreased from 97% to 93%). The superiority of the industrial catalyst under the varying feed rate conditions used is apparent and suggests that further studies will be needed to maintain the activity of the CoCr204 catalyst at higher CO GHSV. 4. Conclusion The performance of high temperature Co-MnO and CoCr204 WGS catalysts was evaluated in coal-derived process gas containing 0.25-0.3 tool% sulfur. At an operating temperature of 400 the Co-MnO catalyst rapidly and irreversibly deactivated, whilst a deactiva- tion-partial reactivation profile was observed for the CoCr204 catalyst. Bulk sulfiding of the Co-MnO catalyst to form C09S8, coupled with a surface man- ganese-sulfide species, was concluded to be respon- sible for the permanent deactivation of this catalyst. By contrast, interaction of sulfur with the Cofr204 catalyst resulted in formation of a surface sulfate species which only caused a partial loss of catalyst activity. Bulk sulfiding of the CoCr204 catalyst at 550 resulted in the formation of CoCrzS4 (and to a lesser extent Co9S8) which is the species thought to be responsible for the sulfur dependent catalyst activ- ity. Indeed, a pre-sulfided CoCr204 catalyst displayed the highest WGS activity in a sulfur rich (0.91 mol%) co-feed at 400. The sulfided cobalt-chromium cata- lyst demonstrated good stability over a range of CO feed rates and CO : H20 ratios. Thus, evidence has been presented to demonstrate high WGS activity of both the oxide and sulfided forms of the cobalt- chromium catalyst in both the presence or absence of trace or concentrated sulfur compounds. Further work to optimize the catalyst is still required. Acknowledgements Financial support from the FRD, AECI Limited and the University of the Witwatersrand is gratefully acknowledged.
